Catseyes: Categorizing Seismic Structures with Tessellated Scattering Wavelet
Networks
CATSEYES: Categorizing Seismic structures with tessellated scattering wavelet networks
Yash Bhalgat1,2, Jean Charléty1, Laurent Duval1

1IFP Energies nouvelles
2Department of Electrical Engineering - IIT Bombay
92852 Rueil-Malmaison, France
Mumbai, Maharashtra 400076, India
{ﬁrstname.lastname}@ifpen.fr
yashsb@umich.edu (now with University of Michigan)
http://www.laurent-duval.eu/opus-cats-eyes-seismic-data-classification-scattering-networks.html

The most natural manner to construct feature vectors (FVs) — to feed classiﬁers
— reduces to using all scattering coeﬃcients. As they result from many couples of
orientations and scales, their size can become extremely large. Exemplar FVs depicted in
Figures 3(d-h-l) have a total length of about 1.5 × 107 coeﬃcients.
However, we observe that the FVs are highly compressible. As ScatNets are energy
preserving, the steep decay indicates that most of the information is carried by
very few important coeﬃcients. Slightly diﬀering decay regimes can be observed
across the diﬀerent classes.
•Guarantee an invariance to gradual local deformations
•Propose a comparison of dimension reduction methodologies

To produce sound images of underground structures, geophysics acquire, model and pro-
cess huge sets of seismic traces, ending up in stacked or migrated datasets (Fig. 1). The
latter represent (distorted because indirect) geological formations in the shape of various
seismic patterns within the wiggling bandpass nature of seismic signals. Their analysis
is of primary importance to understand the tectonic and sedimentary history of regions,
and their potential in ﬁnding hydrocarbon traps.

representation of a two-level scattering transform. Right: ﬂattened feature vectors.

To exploit redundancy in these highly sparse vectors, we ﬁrst benchmark various fea-
ture selection methods [4] collected at Arizona State Universitya.
The feature selec-
tion methods applied to our database are based on: Gini index [5], χ2 statistics [6],
Correlation-based Feature Selection (CFS) [7], Kruskal-Wallis (KW) [8], Minimum Re-
dundancy and Maximum Relevance (mRMR) [9], sparse multinomial logistic regression
algorithm with Bayesian regularisation (SBMLR) [10] and Fisher score [11]. Reduced fea-
ture sizes (#RFS) are globally shrunk again by an order of magnitude, toward thousands
of coeﬃcients

The beauty of seismic structures is that the Sigmoid class can be viewed as a combination
of two classes: Fold and Flat and a Fold or Sigmoid behavior may slowly warp to a Flat
morphology. Hence, we extract and combine FVs from a tessellation of subparts of initial
images. This operation can be thought as a diversity enhancement to account for gradual
morphing between structural monads. In this work,
1 Images (of size 512 × 512) are divided into 4 × 4 = 16 non-overlapping blocks.
2 Scattering wavelet transform coeﬃcients are extracted from each block.

3 Computing the mean of each of the convolutions was shown [2, 3] to correspond to the
energy of the convolutions.

•We adopt scattering wavelet networks as deformation and translation invariant joint
feature extractors and classiﬁers.

•A database with tagged structural monads is devised, drawn on public data, which
could be shared for other publishable studies.

Compressibility of ordered scattering trans-
form feature vectors in log-log-scale.

•An extensive comparison of feature vector sdimension reduction methods for
classiﬁcation is performed
•The proposed tessellated scattering decomposition is shown to be eﬀective.
